Award.AwardTitle: Developmental Mechanisms of Beak Shape Evolution in Galapagos Finches
Award.AbstractNarration: Darwin's Finches are a classic textbook example of evolution by natural selection. Since Charles Darwin, who introduced these birds to science, they have been studied by generations of ecologists and evolutionary biologists. Previous investigations have shown the adaptive significance of their diverse beak shapes, which allow them to survive on distinct food sources. However, the genetic and molecular mechanisms behind these highly adaptive biological shapes remained unknown. Dr. Abzhanov and colleagues recently demonstrated that beak diversity in Darwin's Finches is not random but follows a particular series of mathematical transitions and all their beaks can be classified as sets of related geometric shapes. This project aims to uncover the precise molecular mechanisms by sequencing, comparing and analyzing multiple genes involved in development of distinct beak shapes across Darwin's Finches. It is expected that important new regulatory molecules will be identified and validated using functional experiments. Therefore, biological diversity will be explained both by forces of natural selection and by particular genetic changes that made such adaptations possible. The integration of this work with the long-standing evolutionary, ecological and conservation studies on Darwin's Finches will provide a more mechanistic explanation for evolution in the minds of high school and college textbook writers, school teachers and science news writers and publicists who bring most significant findings to scientific and general public audiences. Investigators will work with the Harvard University Museum of Natural History, which is attended by tens of thousands of K-12 students and teachers each year, to establish a new educational exhibit on bird evolution that will focus on the emergence of the bird face from the reptilian condition and subsequent beak diversification to explain evolutionary processes. Finally, this project will advance training and mentoring of undergraduates, graduate students and post-doctoral fellows and will yield salient research and training research opportunities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Birds are a diverse and the most species-rich group of land vertebrate animals and much of their success is explained by the adaptive diversity of their beaks. The classic textbook example of adaptive evolution by natural selection in birds is the fifteen closely related species of Galápagos (Darwin’s) Finches, whose primary diversity is in the size and shape of their beaks. This natural morphological diversity is associated with the exploitation of various ecological resources and its developmental basis is an inviting research goal. Dr. Abzhanov and collaborators used a combination of advanced morphometrics on beak shapes, comparative developmental analyses, microarrays screens and functional tests to reveal the roles of such important developmental processes as modularity and integration in beak morphological evolution. It was shown that beak diversity in Darwin’s Finches could be reduced to three “group shapes A, B, C”. Beaks within each group are related to each other by scaling transformation, one of the so-called affine transformations used to transform geometric figures into each other, and shear transformation relates members of distinct groups. Dr. Abzhanov’s studies produced significant breakthroughs into the developmental genetic origin of diverse and highly adaptive beak shapes found in Geospiza (group shape “A”). Under this complete project, expression of candidate genes was studied in Tree Finches (group shape “B”). Then, RNA-Seq analysis was used to analyze expression of genes during beaks development and novel candifate genes associated with beak “group shapes” were revealed by comparing multiple members of each group. The new candidate developmental genes are now used for functional tests to reveal their exact developmental and evolutionary roles. The fundamental mechanisms that facilitated adaptive morphological diversity during vertebrate evolution are still poorly understood. This project used the highly adaptive beak shape model to link evolutionary processes with developmental mechanisms to produce data and empirical insights that would be of interest to many in the developmental genetics and evolutionary biology fields.  This study crossed the traditional research boundaries as it incorporated ecological and morphometric studies on one of the iconic evolutionary models, Darwin’s Finches, with genomic, developmental genetics and molecular methods, including functional experiments. The integration of this work with long-standing evolutionary, ecological and conservation studies on Darwin’s Finches provides an opportunity for interdisciplinary research interactions and it also provides a more mechanistic explanation for adaptive morphological evolution in the minds of scientific and general public audiences. This project generated resources valuable to the entire biological community. Principal investigator is proactive in engaging high school and college textbook writers, school teachers and domestic and international science news writers and publicists to bring most significant findings to a wide audience.
